mentions.context: ITK-SNAP provides a great variety of tools for segmenting images, both automatically and manually.
Xarticul offers multiple tools, like an easy way to delineate and process articulator contours, semi-automatic articulatory measurements and construction of articulatory models [12].
Xarticul can perform acoustic simulations from the area function by using the algorithm proposed in [6].This algorithm is based on the Transmission Line Circuit Analog (TLCA) method [18].

Since kwave uses FFT, the number of grid points was set so as to have low prime factors, ideally a power of 2. For the 3D, we used a grid size of 128 × 128 × 128 grid points (sagittal × coronal × axial) with d x = d y = d z = 1mm.
We used Xarticul to manually delineate the articulator contours of each vowel.
Finally we used meshlab [5] to smooth every mesh by applying Laplacian smoothing filter with step 3.
For manual segmentation, ITK-SNAP offers two types of tools, the most interesting among them is the adaptive brush that adjusts itself to follow the image boundaries.
For the acoustic simulations, we used k-wave toolbox for Matlab [26].
Then, we used the tools provided by the ITK-SNAP software to automatically segment the 3D volume of the vocal tract and manually corrected the result.
For the acoustic simulations, we employ the k-wave Matlab toolbox [26].
We apply this algorithm to our data using the FASST toolbox [21].
As far as automatic segmentation is concerned, ITK-SNAP implements two active contour segmentation algorithms, region competition and geodesic active contours [4], [31].
For the purposes of our experiments, we used the ITK-SNAP software [30] to segment the volume of the vocal tract.
For the acoustic simulations, we used k-wave toolbox for Matlab [26].
To perform the electrical simulation we used some of the tools provided from the Xarticul software [16], [22].
We then use it to simulate how the pressure wave produced from the vocal folds propagates with the K-wave Matlab toolkit.
We then use it to simulate how the pressure wave produced from the vocal folds propagates with the K-wave Matlab toolkit.
